Table 1 Sample SBET (m2/g) VP (cm3/g) DP (nm) CoMn3Al0.85 122.3 0.5537 14.20 CoMn3Al 118.8 0.4413 12.30 CoMn3Al1.4 145.8 0.5767 14.21 CoMn3Al1.9 217.2 0.7421 11.83 CoMn3Al1.9-Na 155.7 0.5306 12.22 CoMn3Al1.9-Na (After 5 runs) 130.7 0.2679 11.05 Enhanced oxidation of p-methoxytoluene to p-methoxybenzaldehyde using Na-doped Co-Mn-Al oxide catalysts Tianchi Zhang Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Yaoting Wen Visualization Validation Software Investigation Data curation a Chenglong Xia Software Resources Data curation a Xuhui Xu Writing – review & editing Supervision a Guoping Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision a Jiaxin Guo Software Resources b Yongcai Zhang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Conceptualization b ⁎ a Zhejiang Dayang Biotech Group Co., Ltd., Hangzhou, Zhejiang 311616, China Zhejiang Dayang Biotech Group Co., Ltd Hangzhou Zhejiang 311616 China Zhejiang Dayang Biotech Group Co., Ltd, Hangzhou, Zhejiang 311616, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225009, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University Yangzhou 225009 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225009, China ⁎ Corresponding author. p-Methoxybenzaldehyde (p-MBA) is an important aromatic aldehyde widely used in various industries. Its traditional synthesis methods, such as gas-phase oxidation and chlorination, are hindered by high energy consumption, low selectivity, and environmental concerns. This study explored an alternative greener synthesis of p-MBA through the catalysis of Na-doped Co-Mn-Al oxides (CoMn3Aln-Na), which were derived from calcining coprecipitated layered double hydroxide (LDH). The introduction of Na during the catalyst preparation enhanced the catalytic performance by increasing the conversion of p-MT and the yield of p-MBA. The structural integrity and catalytic stability of the synthesized catalyst materials were confirmed by many characterization techniques. This work has developed a viable strategy for the efficient oxidation of p-methoxytoluene (p-MT) under ambient conditions, thereby contributing to the development of sustainable processes for aromatic aldehyde synthesis. Graphical Abstract Keywords P-Methoxybenzaldehyde (p-MBA) P-methoxytoluene (p-MT) Na-doped catalyst Co-Mn-Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) Liquid-phase oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction p-methoxybenzaldehyde (p-MBA), also known as p-anisaldehyde, is widely employed in flavors and fragrances, daily chemicals, organic synthesis, medicine, agriculture, and other fields [1–4]. Historically, p-MBA was prepared from p-methoxytoluene (p-MT) via gas-phase oxidation using V2O₅ as a catalyst [5–8]. However, gas-phase oxidation typically requires high temperatures, exhibits poor selectivity, and leads to the decomposition of raw materials [9,10]. Currently, liquid-phase catalytic oxidation is the mainstream process for preparing p-MBA due to its economic advantages, milder reaction conditions, and higher selectivity [11,12]. Due to the relatively high dissociation energy of the C(sp³)-H bond in aromatic hydrocarbons, the direct oxidation of these bonds to aldehydes using O2 as an oxidant is both valuable and challenging [13–15]. Although photocatalytic aerobic oxidation exhibits high selectivity for aromatic aldehydes, it generally requires large amounts of solvent and/or results in low feedstock conversion, rendering it unsuitable for industrial applications [16–20]. Chlorination is also used for producing aromatic aldehydes, it employs highly toxic chlorine gas and generates substantial by-products, which contradicts the principles of green chemistry [21]. As sustainable chemistry advances, the design of green synthetic approaches for aromatic aldehydes has become a priority in modern catalytic organic synthesis, spurring efforts to develop novel and efficient catalysts. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) and their derived oxides are currently used as catalysts in various applications, such as volatile organic compound (VOC) degradation, selective oxidation, and selective hydrogenation [22–24]. Also known as hydrotalcite-like compounds, LDHs are synthetic layered materials with a general composition of [ M 1 − x 2 + M x 3 + OH 2 ] x + [ A x / n n − ] x − ·y H 2 O , where M2 + and M3+ represent divalent and trivalent metal cations, respectively [13], An- is an anion of valence n, and x typically ranges from 0.20 to 0.33 [25–28]. Calcined LDHs have attracted significant attention as potential catalysts due to their diverse metal cation combinations, good dispersibility, large specific surface area, and excellent thermal stability [29]. Catalysts composed of one or more transition metal elements (Co, Mn, Ni, Cr, Ce, Cu, etc.) are often employed in liquid-phase catalytic oxidation reactions because these transition metals exhibit multiple oxidation states and high oxygen storage/release capacities [12,13,30–32]. Many studies have demonstrated that the introduction of alkali metals into transition metal oxide catalysts can yield favorable results, as evidenced in processes such as ammonia synthesis [33], Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [34], and VOCs treatment [35]. In the catalytic oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons to aldehydes, adding alkali metals (e.g., Na or K) to the reaction system can inhibit the esterification of aromatic alcohols, thereby enhancing the yield of aromatic aldehydes [36,37]. There are many methods to introduce alkali metals into the reaction system. The simplest approach is the direct addition of soluble alkali salts, but this method also complicates the reuse of the alkali metals [37]. Alternatively, alkali metals can be doped into catalysts via methods such as hydrothermal treatment [38], cation exchange [39], or solid phase reaction [40]. The doping approach facilitates uniform incorporation and improves catalyst reusability. In this study, we developed a green strategy for fabricating LDH catalysts by co-precipitation to incorporate transition metal cations (Co and Mn) and alkali metal sources (NaOH and Na2CO3). Unlike the conventional approach—washing the hydrotalcite before calcination, the present work adopted a reverse sequence: the LDHs were first calcined and subsequently washed to remove undoped Na+ ions. More alkali metals are retained on the surface of the LDHs without being washed, which may be conducive to the doping of alkali metal cations during calcination. The surface of LDHs after calcination will be rich in defects and active sites, increasing the specific surface area [41]. This study presents a novel approach by incorporating sodium doping into the catalyst synthesis process to enhance catalytic performance, in particular, p-MBA is produced via the catalytic oxidation of p-MT. This strategy not only addresses the key challenges in industrial p-MBA synthesis, but also promotes the advancement of catalytic methods for producing aromatic aldehydes from aromatic hydrocarbons. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Preparation of Co-Mn-Al LDHs: Co-Mn-Al LDHs were prepared via a co-precipitation method by maintaining a Co:Mn molar ratio of 1:3 and varying the Al molar ratio to obtain a series of catalysts. Metal salt solution A was prepared by dissolving 0.02 mol Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, 0.06 mol Mn(NO3)2·4 H2O and an appropriate amount of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (0.017, 0.02, 0.028, and 0.038 mol for CoMn3Al0.85, CoMn3Al, CoMn3Al1.4, and CoMn3Al1.9, respectively) in 120 mL deionized water. Alkaline solution B was prepared by dissolving 0.2 mol NaOH and 0.067 mol Na2CO3 in 120 mL deionized water. Solution A and solution B were concurrently introduced dropwise into a four-necked flask, which was placed in a thermostatically controlled oil bath (60 °C) with stirring at 400–800 rpm. The pH was continuously monitored using a Sartorius PB-10 pH meter and maintained within the range of 9.0–9.5 by adding solution A at a slightly higher rate than solution B. Once solution A had been completely added, solution B was incrementally introduced through continuous titration until the pH reached between 9.5 and 10. Finally, the mixture was heated to 80 °C and then aged for 24 h under continuous stirring at 400–800 rpm. Preparation of CoMn 3 Al n catalyst: After aging, the precipitate was filtered and then washed with deionized water until the washings reached a neutral pH, then dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The resulting hydrotalcite precursors were denoted as CoMn3Aln LDHs, where n = 0.85, 1, 1.4, and 1.9, respectively. These precursors were then calcined at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the corresponding Co-Mn-Al metal oxides, denoted as CoMn3Aln (n = 0.85, 1, 1.4, and 1.9), respectively. Preparation of CoMn 3 Al n -Na catalyst: The precipitate obtained after aging was filtered and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The dried precipitate was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h, followed by washing with deionized water until neutrality was achieved. The catalyst was then dried at 100 °C for 12 h to obtain the Na-doped Co-Mn-Al metal oxide, designated as CoMn3Aln-Na. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystallographic phases of the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku SmartLab) over a 2θ range of 5–80° at a scanning speed of 10°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Nexsa G2, Al Kα) was performed with a pass energy of 50 eV and a step size of 0.1 eV to determine the valence state distribution of surface elements. The surface morphology was characterized using field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Supera55 at 10 kV), while transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Philips Tecnai12 at 120 kV) was used to assess particle size, crystallinity, and dispersion. Energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN, maximum accelerating voltage 300 kV, point resolution 0.20 nm, line resolution: 0.102 nm) provided information on elemental distribution. Gas chromatography (Fuli GC9720 Plus) coupled with a flame ionization detector (FID) to determine the composition of reaction products. The specific surface area and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples were determined through Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis using a BSD-PS2 instrument. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was conducted using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 analyzer to investigate the surface acidity and alkalinity of the catalysts. CO2-TPD was employed to characterize the basic sites, while NH3-TPD was used to analyze the acidic sites on the catalyst surface. 2.3 Catalytic oxidation of p-MT Cheap and easily obtained acetic acid was used as the solvent in this experiment. Its polarity and acidity play a crucial role in enhancing the performance of liquid-phase catalytic oxidation [42]. The liquid phase catalytic oxidation of p-MT to prepare aldehydes was carried out in a 300 mL gas-connected reactor (with a PTFE liner), which was connected to an oxygen cylinder via a pressure-reducing valve. The reaction mixture, consisting of a certain amount of p-MT, 40 mL of acetic acid as the solvent, and 0.75 g of Co-Mn-Al catalyst, was heated and stirred in a magnetic oil bath at 105 ℃ with a stirring speed of approximately 250 rpm. An oxygen pressure of 0.3 MPa was maintained throughout the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CoMn3Aln LDHs and CoMn3Aln Fig. 1 shows the powder XRD patterns of the CoMn3Aln LDHs precursors. The CoMn3Aln LDHs (n = 0.85–1.9) exhibit distinct Co-Al hydrotalcite characteristic diffraction lines (marked ●, PDF 51–0045) and characteristic diffraction lines of MnCO3 (marked ◆, PDF 44–1472). However, as the Al content increases, the intensity of the Co-Al hydrotalcite diffraction lines diminishes. In the samples with n = 0.85–1.4, Co-Mn oxides are observed, which are marked as ▼ (PDF 01–1126). When the Al content exceeds 1.4 (CoMn3Al1.4 and CoMn3Al1.9), a new phase, Al(OH)3 (marked ■, PDF 20–0011) is generated. In addition, when the Al content increases to 1.9, the Al(OH)3 phase completely replaces the Co-Mn oxides. The powder XRD patterns of the catalysts obtained after calcination at 400 ℃ are shown in Fig. 2. All Co-Mn-Al catalysts display characteristic diffraction lines for MnO2 (marked ■, PDF 30–0820). In samples with lower Al content (CoMn3Al0.85 and CoMn3Al), Co-Mn oxide (marked ▼, PDF 01–1126) is also detected. As the Al content increases to 1.4–1.9, new characteristic XRD diffraction lines of Co-Al oxide appear (marked ●, PDF 51–0041), corresponding to a defective spinel-like phase. When the Al content increases to 1.9, only MnO2 and Co-Al oxides are present, with Co-Mn oxides disappearing. Interestingly, the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst exhibits an additional XRD diffraction line corresponding to Mn-Na oxide (marked □, PDF 38–0965), suggesting that Na is successfully anchored on the catalyst surface and is chemically associated with Mn. The SEM images of CoMn3Al0.85 LDH, CoMn3Al LDH, CoMn3Al1.4 LDH, and CoMn3Al1.9 LDH are shown in Fig. S1. For the products with the Al content being between 0.85 and 1.4, a well-defined, large hexagonal layered structure is observed. However, the crystallinity of the layered structure of CoMn3Al1.9 LDH is significantly lower than CoMn3Al0.85–1.4 LDHs (Fig. S1), which is consistent with their XRD patterns (Fig. 1). Fig. 3 shows SEM images of the catalysts obtained after calcination at 400 ℃. CoMn3Al0.85, CoMn3Al, and CoMn3Al1.4 retain the layered morphology of the hydrotalcite precursors, indicating that although calcination converts the hydrotalcite into metal oxides (as confirmed by the XRD characterization results in Fig. 2), the layered structure is preserved. Detailed measurements reveal that the layered crystals in CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na are 50–65 nm in size, compared to 85–125 nm for CoMn3Al0.85–1.4. This may be because that higher Al content can inhibit the grain growth of CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na during calcination [43]. TEM analysis ( Fig. 4) confirms that all CoMn3Aln catalysts exhibit a two-dimensional nanosheet structure, demonstrating that the layered structure of their precursors was preserved after calcination at 400 °C. Although the SEM image of the CoMn3Al1.9 catalyst (Fig. 3) does not clearly display the layered structure, the TEM image confirms its layered morphology, suggesting that increased Al content has very minor impact on the intrinsic structure of hydrotalcite. XPS was employed to analyze the oxidation states of the elements on the surface of CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na. As can be seen in Fig. 5, the doping of Na has little effect on the elemental valence states of the CoMn3Al1.9 catalyst. The Mn 2p3/2 region was deconvoluted into two peaks near 642.0 eV and 644.5 eV, suggesting the coexistence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ species in both CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na samples. Moreover, the absence of the typical satellite peak of Mn²⁺ near 646.0 eV demonstrates that Mn does not exist in the divalent state in the two samples [44,45]. In the Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra, the fitted peaks near 785.0 eV and 789.0 eV can be attributed to the satellite features of Co2+ [13,46], the peak at 782.3 eV corresponds to Co2+, whereas the peak at 780.4 eV is characteristic of Co3+ [47]. The Al 2p spectra were fitted into two peaks: the peak with lower binding energy (73.7 eV) is assigned to Al2O3, while the other peak with higher binding energy (75.4 eV) is attributed to Al-OH species [48]. The O 1 s spectra were resolved into three peaks: the peak at the lowest binding energy (∼529.9 eV) is attributed to lattice oxygen (O2-); the peak at ∼531.3 eV corresponds to oxygen species associated with metal oxide defects, such as oxygen vacancy (OV); the ∼532.4 eV peak is assigned to adsorbed water molecules (–OH) on the catalyst surface [13]. Fig. S2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CoMn3Aln and CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalysts, indicating the similar isotherm types of all the samples. The isotherms exhibit a gradual uptake in the low- and medium-pressure regions followed by a sudden increase and a hysteresis loop at the high-pressure region (P/P0 > 0.8). According to the IUPAC classification, the samples have type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating that they are of mesoporous structures [49]. The calculated specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (VP), and pore diameter (DP) are shown in Table 1. The SBET was determined by the BET multi-point method. The SBET increases with the increase of Al content, and CoMn3Al1.9 has the largest SBET (217.2 m2/g). The VP and DP are calculated using the BJH desorption method. CoMn3Al1.9 has the largest VP (0.7421 cm3/g) and the smallest DP (11.83 nm) among all catalysts. In contrast, the Na-doped CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst exhibits a significantly lower SBET (155.7 m²/g) and VP (0.5306 cm3/g) than that of CoMn3Al1.9, while the DP is similar, indicating that Na doping has a greater impact on the specific surface area and pore volume of the mesoporous catalyst, but has a minor impact on the pore diameter [50]. After 5 cycles of catalytic use, the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst exhibited a significant decrease in both SBET and VP. This may be attributed to pore blockage or structural damage during the catalytic reaction, which reduced the catalyst's adsorption–desorption capacity. EDS analysis was primarily employed to investigate the elemental distribution of CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na, with particular emphasis on their Na contents. From their elemental mapping images and EDS spectra ( Fig. 6 a and b), it can be concluded that both samples contain Na. However, the CoMn3Al1.9-Na sample prepared via first calcination and subsequent washing, contain more Na content than the CoMn3Al1.9 sample prepared via first washing followed by calcination. This is because that more Na+ ions would be retained on the surface of the CoMn3Al1.9 LDH precursor without being washed, then during the calcination, Na+ ions underwent diffusion and incorporated into the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst. In practical applications, the Na-doped catalyst surface can neutralize the surface charge and reduce the density of acidic sites on the catalyst surface [51,52]. To investigate the surface acid-base properties of the catalysts, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD measurements were conducted. Both CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na samples exhibited two distinct desorption regions in their CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. S3). A low-temperature peak (∼100 °C) is associated with weak basic sites such as surface hydroxyl groups [53], and a high-temperature peak (∼500–550 °C), is attributed to strong basic sites like lattice O²⁻ species [54]. Similarly, the NH3-TPD results in Fig. 7 also revealed two major NH3 desorption peaks for both catalysts. The low-temperature peak (∼110–130 °C) corresponds to weak Lewis acid sites (e.g., Al3+ and Na+ cations), while the high-temperature peak (∼500–530 °C) is indicative of strong acid sites (Brønsted acid sites), such as metal-oxygen bridge structures [55,56]. Furthermore, Na doping significantly reduces the intensity of Brønsted acid sites, indicating that Na effectively neutralizes these strong acid sites [57], thereby enhancing the catalytic oxidation of C(SP3)-H [52]. Fig. 8 illustrates the conversion rates of p-MT and the yields of main products for CoMn3Aln catalysts with different Al contents. The primary byproduct is p-methoxybenzyl acetate (p-MBAc), while the formation of p-methoxybenzyl alcohol (p-MBAl) is minimal. Catalysts from CoMn3Al0.85 to CoMn3Al1.4 exhibit similar p-MT conversion rates (60–70 %) and p-MBA yields (25–28 %). In contrast, CoMn3Al1.9 has the highest p-MT conversion rate (77.9 %) and p-MBA yield (33.2 %) among these CoMn3Aln catalysts. The performance of each catalyst is basically consistent with its specific surface area. The SBET of CoMn3Al0.85 to CoMn3Al1.4 catalysts show little variation, whereas the SBET of CoMn3Al1.9 is significantly higher than that of other catalysts (Table 1). Next, the performance of CoMn3Al1.9 and CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalysts was evaluated in the experiments with varied amounts of p-MT ( Fig. 9). As the p-MT amount increased from 8 mL to 16 mL, the overall reaction depth decreased when CoMn3Al1.9 was used as the catalyst. The conversion of p-MT sharply decreased from 90.4 % (8 mL p-MT) to 48.3 % (16 mL p-MT), while the yield of p-MBA dropped from 38.3 % (8 mL p-MT) to 18.8 % (16 mL p-MT). Notably, the Na doped CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst significantly enhanced the p-MT conversion (58.2 %) and p-MBA yield (23.7 %) compared with the undoped CoMn3Al1.9. Although Na doping slightly affects the specific surface area of the CoMn3Al1.9 catalyst, it effectively reduces the number of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 7) and enhances the catalytic oxidation ability toward methylbenzene [52]. The p-MT conversion rate and p-MBA formation rate of the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst are also significantly higher than those of other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature (Fig. S5). Fig. 10 presents the results of cyclic tests for the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst. After each cycle, the catalyst was washed 3 times with ethanol and dried before reuse. After the first run, the conversion rate in the subsequent runs (runs 2–5) remained at 50–60 %, and the yield of p-MBA stabilized at approximately 20 %, indicating that the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst exhibits good stability over five consecutive uses. 4 Conclusions In summary, CoMn3Aln (n = 0.85–1.9) hydrotalcite precursors were successfully synthesized via a co-precipitation method and exhibited the characteristic layered structure. After calcination at 400 °C, the layered structure was retained in the resulting Co-Mn-Al metal oxides. Among the Co-Mn-Al metal oxides, CoMn3Al1.9 has a well-defined nanosheet structure, and the highest specific surface area and pore volume. In the liquid-phase catalytic oxidation of p-MT, CoMn3Al1.9 achieved the highest p-MT conversion and p-MBA yield among the CoMn3Aln catalysts. Moreover, Na doping was innovatively introduced by direct calcination of the unwashed hydrotalcite precursors, avoiding the complicated operation of alkali metal doping and facilitating the uniform dispersion. Due to the suppression of Brønsted acid sites, CoMn3Al1.9-Na is superior to undoped CoMn3Al1.9 in p-MT conversion and p-MBA generation. Compared with literature reports, the CoMn3Al1.9-Na catalyst shows clear advantages in the reaction rate of p-MT and the formation rate of p-MBA. This study demonstrates that CoMn3Al1.9-Na has potential application value in liquid-phase catalytic oxidation of aromatics to prepare aromatic aldehyde. coredata.dc:description: p-Methoxybenzaldehyde (p-MBA) is an important aromatic aldehyde widely used in various industries. Its traditional synthesis methods, such as gas-phase oxidation and chlorination, are hindered by high energy consumption, low selectivity, and environmental concerns. This study explored an alternative greener synthesis of p-MBA through the catalysis of Na-doped Co-Mn-Al oxides (CoMn3Aln-Na), which were derived from calcining coprecipitated layered double hydroxide (LDH). The introduction of Na during the catalyst preparation enhanced the catalytic performance by increasing the conversion of p-MT and the yield of p-MBA. The structural integrity and catalytic stability of the synthesized catalyst materials were confirmed by many characterization techniques. This work has developed a viable strategy for the efficient oxidation of p-methoxytoluene (p-MT) under ambient conditions, thereby contributing to the development of sustainable processes for aromatic aldehyde synthesis.
